title: What are the most important supreme court cases? - Quora

response.answer_text: By this time, there’s quite a number, changing people’s lives. But the most important is Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) 137 (1803), where the court introduced the principle of judicial review, that gave the judiciary in general the right to check government (executive and legislative) by striking down illegal government acts. From then, governance wouldn’t be the same. From then, Congress acted with one caution in mind - “what would the courts think?”

Marbury VS Madison. Marbury was a federalist and supporter of John Adams. John Adams wanted to limited the power of the next administration by appointing more people to the courts. However, Marbury appointment was not set to be delivered to the proper authorities until after Thomas Jefferson took office. At this point Thomas Jefferson instructed Madison to not delivered the paper work. So Marbury sued. The court realized that because of federal law that it did not have authority to rule on Marbury case. So the courted ruled that it had the authority to deem a law unconstitutional under the process of judicial review there by expanding its power. Make making it a co equal breach of government.
